theme.title: The bass clef
theme.para: The F clef on the fourth line, also named 'bass clef', is represented by the following symbol:
The bass clef assigns the F note to the 4th line, as shown in following picture:

score.music: (score (vers 1.5) (instrument (musicData (clef F)(key C) (time 2 4 noVisible) (text _''F note'' dx:0 dy:-10) (n f3 w) (barline double noVisible) )))

theme.para: As a result, the staff lines and spaces get automatically assigned to consecutive notes, as shown in the next score:

score.music: (score (vers 1.5) (instrument (musicData (clef F)(key C) (time 2 4 noVisible) (text _''G'' dx:0 dy:-10) (n g2 q) (text _''A'' dx:0 dy:-10) (n a2 q) (text _''B'' dx:0 dy:-10) (n b2 q) (text _''C'' dx:0 dy:-10) (n c3 q) (text _''D'' dx:0 dy:-10) (n d3 q) (text _''E'' dx:0 dy:-10) (n e3 q) (text _''F'' dx:0 dy:-10) (n f3 q) (text _''G'' dx:0 dy:-10) (n g3 q) (text _''A'' dx:0 dy:-10) (n a3 q) (barline double noVisible) )))

theme.para: In the bass clef the first upper leger line corresponds to the central C note (C4), represented in G clef on the first lower leger line:

score.music: (score (vers 1.5) (instrument (musicData (clef G)(key C) (time 2 4 noVisible) (text _''C note'' dx:0 dy:-10) (n c4 w) (barline double) (clef F) (spacer 20) (text _''C note'' dx:0 dy:-25) (n c4 w) (barline double) )))

part.para: In this lesson we are going to start reading the bass clef, while practising the rhythmic patterns studied in previous lessons. We will start reading notes A3, B3 and C4:
